Package es.ulpgc.eii.spool

Class EventBuffer<T extends Event>

java.lang.Object
es.ulpgc.eii.spool.EventBuffer<T>
Type Parameters:
T - the type of Event held in this buffer
public final class EventBuffer<T extends Event> extends Object
A thread-safe, in-memory buffer that accumulates events from a crawler strategy and delivers them as a Stream on demand.

EventBuffer is the glue between the ingestion side (e.g. a Kafka consumer or a webhook endpoint) and the processing side. Events are pushed concurrently from any thread and drained atomically in a single batch.

Internally backed by a ConcurrentLinkedQueue, making it safe for concurrent producers without external synchronization.

Example usage:


 EventBuffer<ParkingEvent> buffer = EventBuffer.initialize();

 // Producer thread
 buffer.push(new ParkingEvent(...));

 // Consumer thread (e.g. scheduled task)
 buffer.drain().forEach(event -> process(event));
Since:
1.0.0

  • Method Details

    • initialize

      public static <T extends Event> EventBuffer<T> initialize()
      Creates a new, empty EventBuffer.

      Prefer the static factory method initialize() for a more expressive instantiation at call sites.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of Event to buffer
      Returns:
      a new empty EventBuffer instance

    • push

      public void push(T event)
      Adds an event to the tail of the buffer.

      This method is thread-safe and non-blocking. Multiple producer threads may call it concurrently without external synchronization.

      Parameters:
      event - the event to enqueue; must not be null

    • drain

      public Stream<T> drain()
      Atomically drains all currently buffered events and returns them as a sequential Stream.

      Events are removed from the buffer as they are collected into a snapshot, so each event is delivered exactly once. Any events pushed after drain() begins will remain in the buffer for the next call.

      Returns:
      a Stream containing all events that were in the buffer at the time of the call; never null, may be empty
